awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Quantifying the effects of a fungus-mediated termite and bark beetle interaction on wood decomposition.
awd_abstract_narration:
The health, conservation and management of forests depends on accurate models predicting the rate at which trees die and decompose. Currently, such models assume the rate at which dead wood decomposes is primarily a function of the temperature, tree type and available moisture. Recent evidence suggests that wood-consuming decomposer organisms may be nearly as important in determining the rate of wood decay as these environmental factors. Bark beetle infestations in forests generate massive amounts of dead wood during outbreaks.  During bark beetle epidemics, termites create biological hotspots in and around the dead trees in which they feed.  This, in turn, influences the abundance and diversity of subsequent decomposer organisms.  Preliminary findings from a forest in in the Southeastern USA indicate that fungi carried to trees by bark beetles increase the rate at which termites consume wood containing these fungi. This EAGER project will use intense field studies to determine whether the interaction between bark beetles, fungi and termites is widespread in other forests in North and South America.  This discovery may help solve a critical need to understand why dead wood in forests often decomposes at more variable rates than expected based on temperature. The project will include training opportunities at the undergraduate and graduate levels.  As part of the project, a permanent termite display will be constructed at the Mississippi Entomological Museum, and project findings will be disseminated via a popular social media webpage.

The objective of this project is to experimentally quantify the importance of this newly-discovered fungus-mediated interaction between bark beetles and subterranean termites on wood decomposition rates in a wide array of coniferous forests (tropical, subtropical, and arid) that contain ongoing bark beetle epidemics and three distinct levels of subterranean termite abundance and diversity. Three field sites will be established, each with an experiment that manipulates presence/absence of the fungus and subsequently quantifies differences in composition of the decomposer communities and rate of wood decay. Meteorological data (temperature, precipitation), termite and other woodboring insect abundance and diversity, fungal community data, wood and soil heterotrophic respiration data, and wood decomposition data we be collected at each site. In this way, this study will determine the relative importance of this biological interaction in mediating wood decomposition across a variety of climactic zones. Ecosystem processes such as decomposition are currently treated as a black box in models, with little focus on interactions among decomposers. The recently discovered link between two ecosystem engineers (bark beetles and termites) may be a significant driver of carbon fluxes in many forest ecosystems, and therefore may have significant impact on the future conceptual frameworks employed to quantify and model wood decomposition rates.

por.por_cntn:
Forest ecosystems cover a significant portion of Earth and function as a major source of carbon storage. In particular, deadwood is an often overlooked, but important, component of forest ecosystems, carbon storage, and home to significant biodiversity. Frequent and widespread deadwood inputs in global forest ecosystems are generated from bark beetles. Bark beetles are tiny insects that are strong in number when they enmass attack and ultimately kill coniferous trees. In doing so, they infect the trees with a suite of symbiotic fungi that stain the tree wood blue. These fungi do not decompose the wood, but some were recently discovered to attract termites, which are major wood decomposers and may alter fungal colonization patterns during wood decomposition. If bark beetle attacked trees have increased termite presence, then this is likely to accelerate decomposition of deadwood and may accelerate carbon cycling. Given bark beetle attacks are increasing in frequency and distribution due to global climate change, this is likely to have big impacts on decomposition processes in forests worldwide, but has not been previously studied.

We investigated whether bark beetle attacked trees undergo different decomposition processes and harbor different suites of fungi and invertebrates, like termites, than unattacked trees in three sites that varied in termite densities, temperature and precipitation: Mississippi, USA (MS), Siguatepeque, Honduras (HN), and Arizona, USA (AZ). At each site one recently bark beetle attacked and one unattacked tree were felled and cut into 60 sections. Half of each tree type was collected after 1 year and the other half after 2 years. Bark beetle attacked trees decomposed faster than unattacked trees and decomposition was fastest in MS and HN. This was likely driven mainly by decomposer insects like termites in MS and fungi in HN and AZ. Termites were most frequently encountered in deadwood in MS and least in AZ, where no termites were found. 

Together, this research demonstrated that bark beetle-attacked trees do in fact undergo significantly different decomposition processes than unattacked trees, and these differences are largest when termites are abundant and have access to wood. Moreover, our wood nutrient analyses and fungal diversity analyses demonstrated that nutrient dynamics are impacted both by bark beetle attack and by termite access to wood. These results have implications for forest ecosystem management and global carbon cycle modeling.

This research not only demonstrated how a novel relationship between bark beetle attacked trees and termites impacts wood decomposition, it had significant broader impacts. This project facilitated an international collaboration between the Honduran Universidad Nacional de Ciencias Forestales, three United States Universities, and the USDA Forest Service. Through this collaboration, we were able to present information about this project to over ~400 Honduran forestry students and at a joint meeting in Tegucigalpa, HN between the USA and Honduras Governments on managing and combatting bark beetle outbreaks. This project also supported the training of more than a dozen undergraduate and graduate students. This research was presented by students and PIs to stakeholders, the public, and other scientists at seven conferences and generated three peer-reviewed journal publications to date. Through the creation of a live, interactive termite exhibit in the Mississippi State Entomological Museum, the importance of termites to wood decomposition and their interaction with bark beetle-associated fungi is on display for the hundreds of children and adults visiting the museum annually.
